conclusion: The diagram shows a process where an ideal gas goes from state A to state C via state B. From the diagram: A → B: Isobaric process (constant pressure) B → C: Isochoric process (constant volume).
We're given: Temperature at state A: $-73°C = 200$ K Change in internal energy from A to C: $\Delta U = 200$ J Goal: Find heat Q exchanged between gas and environment from A to C.
From the diagram, at state A: $p_A = 3 \times 10^5$ Pa, $V_A = 1 \times 10^{-3}$ m³ = 1 L.

premise: From the diagram, at state A: $p_A = 3 \times 10^5$ Pa, $V_A = 1 \times 10^{-3}$ m³ = 1 L.
conclusion: n = \frac{p_A V_A}{R T_A} = \frac{(3 \times 10^5 \text{ Pa})(1 \times 10^{-3} \text{ m}^3)}{(8.314 \text{ J/mol·K})(200 \text{ K})} = \frac{0.3}{1662.8} = 0.18 \text{ mol}

premise: Work done = Area under the curve in p-V diagram. For A → B: Work done = $p_A \times (V_B - V_A) = 3 \times 10^5 \times (4 - 1) \times 10^{-3} = 3 \times 10^5 \times 3 \times 10^{-3} = 900$ J For B → C: No work done (constant volume)
Using the First Law of Thermodynamics: $Q = \Delta U + W$ Where: $Q$ is the heat exchanged $\Delta U$ is the change in internal energy $W$ is the work done by the system

conclusion: We can double-check using the properties of an ideal gas: For monatomic gas: $\Delta U = \frac{3}{2}nR\Delta T$ For diatomic gas: $\Delta U = \frac{5}{2}nR\Delta T$
From the diagram: State A: $T_A = 200$ K, $p_A = 3 \times 10^5$ Pa, $V_A = 1 \times 10^{-3}$ m³ State C: $p_C = 1 \times 10^5$ Pa, $V_C = 4 \times 10^{-3}$ m³

premise: We can find $T_C$ using the ideal gas law: $T_C = \frac{p_C V_C}{nR} = \frac{(1 \times 10^5)(4 \times 10^{-3})}{0.18 \times 8.314} = \frac{0.4}{1.49652} = 267.3$ K
conclusion: Since we know $\Delta U = 200$ J, this confirms our approach is reasonable.
